 The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) signed into law by former President Clinton in 1996 will prevent the forced recognition of foreign same-sex marriages for federal purposes. The DOMA defines marriage as the union of one man and one woman, specifying that a person's spouse must always be a member of the opposite sex.
 
 Additionally, 37 states currently have their own DOMA laws, which puts into place yet another barrier to homosexual activists seeking to have a foreign same-sex marriage sanctioned in the U.S.

 Yes, indeed it did come in the middle of the night.
 You see Clinton outright lied to the gay community. He said he was a champion for gay rights, yet when push came to shove, the gay community relied on Clinton and he folded to pressure from the GOP. 
 
 The same thing happened with "Don't Ask, Don't tell." It was the first example of Clinton's inability to stand up to the GOP. He caved on that issue as well, after promicing the Gay community that he would back them up. 
 It was a slight of hand on his part. A backhanded insult which the gay community was not prepaired for. 
 
 Now, after being backhanded that way, they are mad as hell. Not that I can blame them. Being a member of the GLBT community, I too felt betrayed by Clinton. We put our faith in him to do what was right for human rights and in return we got shafted. 
 
 Since then we have become more aware of the GOP's intent when they forced Clinton's hand. We know now that it was their intention to not only inact DOMA but to push more legislation which would further make it impossible to repeal DOMA via the "Protection of Marriage Act" H.R.3313, which was recently passed by Congress, as a back up measure after FMA (Federal Marriage Amendment) failed. 
 
 
 Hope this helps.

 You are once again resorting to a know fallacy
 
 Appeal To Widespread Belief (Bandwagon Argument, Peer Pressure, Appeal to Common Practice): 
 the claim, as evidence for an idea, that many people believe it, or used to believe it, or do it. 
 If the discussion is about social conventions, such as "good manners", then this is a reasonable line of argument. 
 
 However, in the 1800's there was a widespread belief that bloodletting cured sickness. All of these people were not just wrong, but horribly wrong, because in fact it made people sicker. Clearly, the popularity of an idea is no guarantee that it's right. 
 
 Similarly, a common justification for bribery is that "Everybody does it". And in the past, this was a justification for slavery.
